block.p: ''Oceans Are Rising,'' ''Beaches Are Closed by Sewage and Debris,'' ''Acid Rain Imperils Adirondacks Fish,'' ''Drought Evokes Fear.'' These are a sample of recent headlines on your news articles and letters. These dolorous disclosures have been, with scores of others in the same vein, appearing almost continually, yet the seriousness of what they alert us to has still to appear disturbing enough to our political leadership to produce action massive enough to match the damage that must be contained and reversed.

It is surely puzzling to those who observe the growing danger to our environment and to the resources that make life on earth possible that so little concern is evident from the leaders in whom we vest the power to cope with our problems. Excessive concern instead is given to such pseudo-economic enterprises as stock and futures markets, which are merely arenas for money transactions with the aim of shifting money from one pocket to another.

Meanwhile, the source of wealth and life support gets attention only if enough screaming surmounts the babble to gain attention. The lungs of those who perceive these disasters seem inadequate to overwhelm the noise. SAM ZASLAVSKY New York, July 7, 1988
